blog.description:
'Game of Thrones & a Parting Glass' lives here, don't ask why, but you can search by character or author if you wish. and sometimes i snap photos, write words, and paint pictures. and sometimes i realize it's all futile. <!-- Start of StatCounter Code for Tumblr -->

summary: what's your wish list that would happen in GOT S8 ep1, ep 2, ep 3,,ep 4, ep5  & ep 6?
question: what's your wish list that would happen in GOT S8 ep1, ep 2, ep 3,,ep 4, ep5  & ep 6?
answer:
Episode 1- Jon and the Dragonstone crew arrive at Winterfell. We get the most epic and deserved Stark reunion of all time with Jon and Arya. Jon and Bran also reunite and I want it to be super emotional since Jon never got to say a proper goodbye to Bran. Dany gets to meet the Starks and the Starks meet Drogon and Rhaegal.


Episode 2- Arya and Dany bond over their love for Jon. Arya tells Dany about Nymeria and she tells Arya about how Drogon came back to her. Arya officially welcomes Dany into her pack and Dany gets the family she deserves. 


Episode 3-6- The White Walkers are defeated and we get some serious bad ass dragon action and battle sequences and Nymeria returns with a pack attack. I want all of our faves to be happy. I just want them all to get some peace and happiness ^.^.

blog.name: iheartgot
blog.title: IHEARTGOT
blog.description:
IHEARTGOT is dedicated to the HBO television series Game of Thrones, which is based on the A Song of Ice and Fire novels written by George R. R. Martin, and its cast. We update daily to bring you the latest pictures, edits, gifs and more of the show and the books. 
This is NOT a spoiler-free blog.
We track #iheartgot.

summary: Happy (Belated) Birthday @bitchfromtheseventhhell It is Winterfell that Bran sees first, from the heart tree in the godswood....
body:
Happy (Belated) Birthday @bitchfromtheseventhhell

It is Winterfell that Bran sees first, from the heart tree in the godswood.

“You saw what you wished to see,” Leaf tells him. “Your heart yearns for your father and your home, so that is what you saw.”

It hurts, to see Father and not be able to speak with him, not on the first time, or the second, or the third, fourh or fifth. Leaf is right, Bran sees what his heart wishes to see, and his heart wishes to see Father no matter how much Lord Brynden tells him he must push aside those feelings for the hour is late, and he must rule his gifts and not let his gifts rule him.

Jojen once told him something similar, back when he first opened his third eye.

“I’ll try,” he promises.

He fails, over and over. His heart yearns not just for Father, but for Jon, and Robb, Arya and Sansa and his little brother Rickon. He thought never to see Robb again but a greenseer can see all, and Robb is alive once more at Winterfell, praying in front of the heart tree with Father and Jon.

Jon prays silently, misery etched in his features until Robb drapes an arm around his shoulders.

“You’ll always have a place here,” he says quietly to Jon.

The heart tree weeps as Bran watches, and Father’s face is long and sad as he looks at the boys, almost as if he knows. Jon left Winterfell and he won’t ever return,.  Like Robb he is dead, and Bran can’t bear to watch any longer, not when only days ago he spoke to Jon as a raven in Castle Black.

I won’t let anybody else die. I won’t.

It doesn’t matter what Lord Brynden tells him, it’s Rickon he sees next. His fierce little brother keeps Shaggy close, and Osha is with him. Skagos has a lot of heart trees, and Bran can keep a close watch. He speaks to his little brother, and Rickon is the first to hear him.

“Bran?”

He knows me. It’s on account of Osha, the wildling who understands more of the old gods than those south of the Wall, but it’s Rickon who believes. He’s frightened at first, frightened that it means Bran has died but Osha helps, and Rickon hears enough of Bran’s words to understand.

“I want to see Mother,” Rickon tells him. “Tell her I want her.”

Mother is dead.

He doesn’t tell Rickon, because he can’t say how he knows but he knows. Bran wants Mother too, to speak with her, to see her. His powers grow, he begins to see beyond the heart trees with Lord Brynden’s teaching and then he sees across fields, through woods, and into caves.where the roots of the trees grow deep.

It is in the cave that he learns that he’s wrong.

Mother.

She’s not dead, but not truly alive either. She’s not his Mother, who kissed his brow, and told him not to climb, and sang to him, and tucked him into bed.

“Hang them,” she croaks.

No, you mustn’t. Mother please.

He has no face in the cave, no mouth, and she doesn’t hear him. She doesn’t speak of him either, only of Robb and Arya and Sansa. She is forever seeking his sisters, but Bran knows she won’t find them, not like that. He doesn’t want her to find them.

My mother is dead.

He cries that night, trying to hide his tears so that he doesn’t look like a baby. A baby can’t fight the Others, and a baby won’t find his sisters. When he closes his eyes, his mind reaches beyond the trees, through leagues and leagues across the seven kingdoms.

Arya.

It’s Nymeria he sees, but he can feel his sister. The sight of the wolf, the connection to another warg, fills him with joy. Arya is alive. He told himself she was, but it had been so long, and so many of his visions were of people who thought her dead. She is far away, he can sense that, but if he can reach her wolf Bran knows he can reach Arya.

Arya, he calls to the wolf and Nymeria stills, looking at him, at the tree.

We’ll fight together when you come back.

He just needed to find Sansa, but that was turning out to be more difficult than he expected, even with his growing powers.

She lost her wolf.

He refuses to believe she is dead. He’d know if she was, like he knew about Father and Robb and Mother and Jon. Sansa is there, somewhere, within rock that is beyond his view. He looks for her, with purpose, the way Lord Brynden taught him. He sees her in Kings Landing, but that is not now, he has learned how to tell.

“Monsters,” she whispers.

The demons of the dark can’t get you if you hide under your blankets. Sansa told him that once. He wishes she was right now, and he tries harder to see, to go forward in time but he goes back instead. His sisters sleep in the strange godswood without its heart tree, but Father is awake, and Bran smiles through his tears until he sees Sansa stirring.

“I dreamed of Bran,” Sansa whispers. “I saw him smiling.”

It startles him, to think she might see him, but that’s stupid. She can’t see him but the thought is enough to pull him out of the vision.

I’ll find her, he tells himself in the days and weeks that follow. He tries hard to follow Lord Brynden’s teaching, knowing so many people need him to learn. He has to learn for Rickon and Arya, and for Jon who wakes up not at all like Mother and makes Bran cry again, unashamedly this time. He’ll learn for Meera too, who has given up so much for him to be here, and Hodor who takes care of him.

He’ll learn for Sansa, because one day he will find her, and when he does he’ll be the one to keep her safe from the demons of the dark.

He’ll keep them all safe.

Leaf is right, Bran sees what his heart wishes to see, and his heart wishes to see Father no matter how much Lord Brynden tells him he must push aside those feelings for the hour is late, and he must rule his gifts and not let his gifts rule him.

Jojen once told him something similar, back when he first opened his third eye.

“I’ll try,” he promises.

He fails, over and over. His heart yearns not just for Father, but for Jon, and Robb, Arya and Sansa and his little brother Rickon. He thought never to see Robb again but a greenseer can see all, and Robb is alive once more at Winterfell, praying in front of the heart tree with Father and Jon.

Jon prays silently, misery etched in his features until Robb drapes an arm around his shoulders.

“You’ll always have a place here,” he says quietly to Jon.

The heart tree weeps as Bran watches, and Father’s face is long and sad as he looks at the boys, almost as if he knows. Jon left Winterfell and he won’t ever return,.  Like Robb he is dead, and Bran can’t bear to watch any longer, not when only days ago he spoke to Jon as a raven in Castle Black.

I won’t let anybody else die. I won’t.

It doesn’t matter what Lord Brynden tells him, it’s Rickon he sees next. His fierce little brother keeps Shaggy close, and Osha is with him. Skagos has a lot of heart trees, and Bran can keep a close watch. He speaks to his little brother, and Rickon is the first to hear him.

“Bran?”

He knows me. It’s on account of Osha, the wildling who understands more of the old gods than those south of the Wall, but it’s Rickon who believes. He’s frightened at first, frightened that it means Bran has died but Osha helps, and Rickon hears enough of Bran’s words to understand.

“I want to see Mother,” Rickon tells him. “Tell her I want her.”

Mother is dead.

He doesn’t tell Rickon, because he can’t say how he knows but he knows. Bran wants Mother too, to speak with her, to see her. His powers grow, he begins to see beyond the heart trees with Lord Brynden’s teaching and then he sees across fields, through woods, and into caves.where the roots of the trees grow deep.

It is in the cave that he learns that he’s wrong.

Mother.

She’s not dead, but not truly alive either. She’s not his Mother, who kissed his brow, and told him not to climb, and sang to him, and tucked him into bed.

“Hang them,” she croaks.

No, you mustn’t. Mother please.

He has no face in the cave, no mouth, and she doesn’t hear him. She doesn’t speak of him either, only of Robb and Arya and Sansa. She is forever seeking his sisters, but Bran knows she won’t find them, not like that. He doesn’t want her to find them.

My mother is dead.

He cries that night, trying to hide his tears so that he doesn’t look like a baby. A baby can’t fight the Others, and a baby won’t find his sisters. When he closes his eyes, his mind reaches beyond the trees, through leagues and leagues across the seven kingdoms.

Arya.

It’s Nymeria he sees, but he can feel his sister. The sight of the wolf, the connection to another warg, fills him with joy. Arya is alive. He told himself she was, but it had been so long, and so many of his visions were of people who thought her dead. She is far away, he can sense that, but if he can reach her wolf Bran knows he can reach Arya.

Arya, he calls to the wolf and Nymeria stills, looking at him, at the tree.

We’ll fight together when you come back.

He just needed to find Sansa, but that was turning out to be more difficult than he expected, even with his growing powers.

She lost her wolf.

He refuses to believe she is dead. He’d know if she was, like he knew about Father and Robb and Mother and Jon. Sansa is there, somewhere, within rock that is beyond his view. He looks for her, with purpose, the way Lord Brynden taught him. He sees her in Kings Landing, but that is not now, he has learned how to tell.

“Monsters,” she whispers.

The demons of the dark can’t get you if you hide under your blankets. Sansa told him that once. He wishes she was right now, and he tries harder to see, to go forward in time but he goes back instead. His sisters sleep in the strange godswood without its heart tree, but Father is awake, and Bran smiles through his tears until he sees Sansa stirring.

“I dreamed of Bran,” Sansa whispers. “I saw him smiling.”

It startles him, to think she might see him, but that’s stupid. She can’t see him but the thought is enough to pull him out of the vision.

I’ll find her, he tells himself in the days and weeks that follow. He tries hard to follow Lord Brynden’s teaching, knowing so many people need him to learn. He has to learn for Rickon and Arya, and for Jon who wakes up not at all like Mother and makes Bran cry again, unashamedly this time. He’ll learn for Meera too, who has given up so much for him to be here, and Hodor who takes care of him.

He’ll learn for Sansa, because one day he will find her, and when he does he’ll be the one to keep her safe from the demons of the dark.

He’ll keep them all safe.
trail.content_abstract:
Happy (Belated) Birthday @bitchfromtheseventhhell

It is Winterfell that Bran sees first, from the heart tree in the godswood.

“You saw what you wished to see,” Leaf tells him. “Your heart yearns for your father and your home, so that is what you saw.”

It hurts, to see Father and not be able to speak with him, not on the first time, or the second, or the third, fourh or fifth. Leaf is right, Bran sees what his heart wishes to see, and his heart wishes to see Father no matter how much Lord Brynden tells him he must push aside those feelings for the hour is late, and he must rule his gifts and not let his gifts rule him.

Jojen once told him something similar, back when he first opened his third eye.

“I’ll try,” he promises.
